reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: Edited for second launch (more on this below)
This game reminds me of some of the old strategy based flash games I used to play, though in more detail. It's a bit rough in some places, but the two-man dev team has taken this an impressive distance in a short time.

In short:This reminds me of some of the strategic flash games I used to play years ago, although in more depth. There -used- to be a cash shop which got removed when the game went to a paid model due to people criticising there being one. There was nothing exclusively available to the cash shop anyway, but kudos to the devs for taking this step (the 'second launch' was the removal of the cash shop).

One of the biggest plusses of this game are the developers themselves. They're very responsive, listen to criticism (my initial review was pretty scathing, read the comments on this review), and actively patch bugs/add features (you can see this in the discussion forums).

Since you're probably already aware of what's right with the game, I'll list what's wrong. The UI could use a bit of work for user convenience still, but it still conveys the information it needs to. The graphics are decent, but in some areas a tad on the boring side, though the solo artist is working on improving them constantly. My last and largest issue is that there's nothing that truly sets this game apart from others in the genre currently, though part of this is due to it still being early access, and I've seen this being improved on steadily.

For the obligatory x/10 rating, I'd give it a 7.5/10 for it's current state. It might be worth picking up if you're into this genre, and it doesn't look like it'll be ditched any time soon given how much love the devs have put into it.

=====================
Pros & Cons (w/suggestions)
=====================
PROS:
+ Active & swift development (check discussions)
+ Developers will listen to suggestions
+ Responsible developer(s) (see also: not a cash grab)
+ Touches on a genre that's been inactive for years, and brings some new features & ideas to the table
+ Interesting approach to the graphics side (3D graphics)
+ Random/Procedurally generated dungeon
+ Complex stats/resistances, to allow for in-depth strategy
+ Mutliple classes (with more being added)
+ Has high score system
+ Doesn't take a top-of-the-line system to run smoothly (fairly well optimized)
+ Decent amount of abilities/skills/passives, with more on the way
+ Presents a decent challenge at bosses, and each boss has a gimmick

CONS:
- Controls are not intuitive (they can be rebound though)
- Unwieldy UI at times
- Could use more music/sounds
- Not much lore currently
- Maximum level limited to 50 due to current content (subject to change)

POSSIBLE IMPROVEMENTS
= Show mana/hp regen amount in stats
= Add an easily viewable EXP meter with the HP/MP meters in the portrait frame area.
= Lore, lore, lore
= Ability to select race at world generation
= Use of color and images in text for combat log -- red for damage, green for health regened, some sort of image to indicate the event (like the image associated with the skill used)
= Floor curses/blessings
= Add a boss room map icon
= Make it possible to compare 1h weapons to 2h weapons
= Make it possible to compare a ring to both currently equipped rings (simultaneously)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit to include my opinion of the recent updates:

From the very short amount of time I played of this before writing this review, I find the game to be fun and I definitely recommend trying it. My only real issues are with the music and the amount of enemy encounters.

Pros:

+Very well made, they included things I thought they might not such as where you place your party for engagements and a pretty enjoyable loot system. I've found some pretty strong starter weapons and armors so I can pretty easily take down the enemies I'm encountering.

+The game doesn't seem to require much of your PC in order to play so I feel like anyone who is into first person dungeon crawlers but can't afford a better rig to play some of the more high-end ones will enjoy this.

+They added footfalls into the sound pool. While they do sound rather 90's, I don't mind that. It fits with the era that this game seems to be in. It feels like a very 90's game, and it feels great. I really do like that about this game.

Cons:

- The music is literally the same song throughout the whole game with no pause even during loading screens. It's a nice song but I feel like that should be the song that plays in town and there should be a separate song that plays during dungeon crawling (or no song at all, for more atmosphere).

- Probably my only gripe (it's more of a personal one) is the amount of enemies you encounter. When you open a door, it's either a group of enemies, a lore book, or a chest. 80% of the time it's enemies. It doesn't matter much and I feel like I'd enjoy this system more if I kept playing, but it's just a personal gripe. Keep it in, I'll get used to it. Especially if there's ambient noise to accompany my time spent in the dungeon.


This is a free game so there are some paid elements but I don't feel like you NEED to spend money on this game to do well. I've been doing pretty good so far without seeing any reason to spend money on the game, but someone might find something as I haven't played very much. I'd say give this game a try right now. If it's not your cup of tea, try it in a couple months after some patches roll out and the game becomes better. I really do like this game, it's a lot of fun and the developers listen to feedback from the community. If you like developer inclusion and 90's first person dungeon crawlers, download this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great little dungeon crawler type game.. well in this case you climb Zavix Tower.  Old school RPG stype starting with a Warrior, Rogue, Mage and Cleric.  There are micro transactions sure, you'll receive a flashing icon in the top left of your screen, if you're not interested in paying, dont.  I am enjoying the game and I haven't lost a character yet, there is absolutely no need for the gems / ingame currency.  This game is fully playable without spending, I want to make that perfectly clear, this is NOT a money grab.

It is a wonderfully constructed old school RPG that will find a slot in your day when you want to hit some baddies with your crew of bearded ladies and hunched over old cronies tossing fireballs and smiting your foes !

Each floor will give you the opportunity to return back to town or climb the next level, but once you go up, you must reach the next level of stairs to go back, so do not make that decision lightly, and you'll love this game.  Make good choices, think ahead..

Love it 8/10
voteText: 16 of 18 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't normally like dungeon crawlers, but  this game has made me more attracted to the genre with its party set-ups, grinding floors and combat system, even in its currently unfinished state. My only major qualms with it are its single looping song, and its slight over-abundance of enemy encounters. I think it could also use a consumable item or two, to bring along with the party into the tower. Since the shrines cover healing, perhaps the items could increase the likelihood of finding a shrine or some such.
The lore books are a great touch, the healing shrines are wonderful in a pickle, and the chests are great for getting much-needed gear. It's a great game for any rpg-lover.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Zavix Tower is a turn based dungeon crawler that, as of this review only recently released on Steam. I have enjoyed what I have played so far, From the loot based upgrades, unforgiving combat and charming, if basic visuals.  The hub world, or town and cash shop gives me pretty heavy mobile vibes, but if you can get past it I feel the gameplay is more than decent.

To start you get four party members you can chose from four classes for each of them, warrior, priest, rogue, and mage.  Each class has a variety of uses in combat, but each fills a standard roll, warriors generally make the best tanks, mages do tons of ranged dps, etc. You're members are arranged on a two by six grid, and each member attacks in sequence with all other party members or enemies in the current room of the dungeon. Each turn usually goes by quick, so even though combat is turn based it can move pretty fast.

Honestly from what I have played there is not a whole lot more to it than that. Zavix Tower is currently in early access so I expect to see at least some changes at some point. but on the off chance that we don't I still think its pretty neat and would recommend you try it if you are looking for a free to play dungeon crawler.
voteText: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having played alot of turn-based dungeon crawlers in the past, I had an inkling of what to expect coming in but to my surprise, there were lots of new elements that kept the game new and enjoyable but it still kept true to its genre - hence this being honored with my first review.

The game at the moment is still very early on in its development but is on track to being something potentially amazing. Characters are customizable (personally something I absolutely love/need in games) and the graphics are very pleasing and interesting. The combat is incredibly intuitive and challenging, forcing you to think ahead and about each and every turn you make. Yet the progression in the tower is not impossible, I always feel as though I'm constantly getting upgrades and making lots of progress. The in-game shop is there and available but I don't feel like it is necessity as everyone seems to make it out to be and everything seems to be available and possible just by playing and being smart about your decision making.

No game is perfect though and there are elements that are obviously in need of fine-tuning and changing. For one, at the moment there is not much variety for music choice. Also there isn't much explanation, or lore, in the begining to help players to ease into the game. This is clear to everyone else, and possibly the developers as well, but I'm more then sure this will change in the near future.

Again, everything is still in early access and the game is not anywhere near completion. I would more than recommend at least checking it out as it is free to play since there's nothing to lose!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to start out by saying I was a part of the alpha,.

That being said the game has come a LONG LONG way in the last month, and the devs have made good on their promises so far. The game is by no means finished, so if your looking for a finished AAA quality game then you probably will need to wait a bit.

The gameplay is pretty darn good, with more mobs and bosses being added. The item system is still be bit generic, but its solid none the less. Graphics have been coming up steadily, and so have the features. I love that I have been able to play the whole time without spending any more (though the starter pack the just put up is very temping).

overall its a good skeleton of a game, and its headed in the right direction.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have reccommended this game to a few friends and gave them the requirement to play for 10-20 mins before making a decisioin. Every one of them played 3+ hours their first session.

This game has an amazing start to be something great. The characters grow on you as you play and build into their strengths. I find myself getting more and more attaached to each character as I play. Some of these games force you to swap out characters for arbitrary reasons and they usually loose me there.

Items seem really well done even in the beginning. I always feel like I am getting minor upgrades as I progress.

I LOVE that alot of in game purchaces can be earned with in game currency. Do your daillies so that you can earn crystals and getting unlocks.

Battle is very intuitive and all of the data I need seems to be at your finger tips if you take the few seconds to look for it.

Keep up the good work on this. I am looking forward to more to come as this game gets closer to completion!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It looks pretty decent, has low hardware requirements, and has such great potential that I really want to recommend it. Unfortunately, it appears to be designed as a requiring microtransactions to make any real progress. Documentation is lacking (tutorial hasn't been created yet, but is promised; there is no manual to explain which key does what; some routine things in othergames don't happen here - eg can only heal or regain mana in combat.)

When you go into the dungeon there is only 1 way out (other than every 5th level - maybe, I never got that far) - and that is through the morgue. Unfortuantely, characters cost 100x level gold to revive, while with a starting party you can expect to have to clear 15 to 20 rooms of monsters to earn 100 gold. Sadly your mana and health will likely run out in about one third that many rooms (or less if you run into higher level monsters...) meaning you are only going backwards unless you buy gold or crystals to revive dead characters...

If there was an alternative to yes and no, I'd choose it. The game is still in early access, so it may well change before final release. I'll try again at that time and update my review afterwards.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*A special shoutout and thanks to the Dev team for letting me try this early**

I guess I'll start on sections and go from there.

The gameplay:
You start out as a young party(Mage, Rogue, Warrior,Priest) stationed in a small bumbling town. In the town you have a Chapel (To revive lost party members), an Inn (To add armor and to alter characters), a Blacksmith(To buy/sell), and a Dojo" (To get new spells or abilities for your character). You have the right to change a characters abilities
hoursPlayed: and thier attributes. Doing so will improve thier stats and your chance in the dungeon tower.\n\nYour main objective is to survive as long as possible in the dungeon tower. In it you will encounter rabid wolves
voteText: slimes
votesTotal: ect.\n\nThe combat system is quite simple. You set your party up for who's infront and who's behind. You click on the desired attack or magic spell and it swings at the monster. You
commentsCount:
have to watch your mana and your health while maintaining the monsters at hand.

In the dungeon tower you can find chests which contain common to epic items. The map is a little hectic and I've gotten lost inside of the dungeon tower.

Dying in the dungeon tower makes a character lose items and xp that could've been gained. The higher the level
column16:
the bigger risk and better the reward is.

F2P:
You can get upgrades. They are for town upgrades
column19:
or respec'ing your character's abilities/attributes. PAYING FOR SHARDS DOES NOT EFFECT COMBAT. (Aka your strength does not depend on how much money you spend) All of these can be earned so it's not a P2W game even though there is grinding involved.

Improvements and thoughts:

The map system and control system inside the dungeon tower needs to be worked. I demand arrows and a little blip to help me find my way out. I'm not currently impressed with the combat system
column20: but I have been told a lot more characters are coming out to widen the variety. I hope that the DEV's also place in dungeon rooms such as traps
column22: maybe some characters who heal/talk to you. It's a skeleton currently and it's not a terrible idea. If anything
column23: it reminds me of my early Ps1 days.\n\nKeep on improving the good work. Hope you like my review."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I didn't expect much from this game, but as an Early Access title that's free I decided to give it a chance, and I was quite satisfied. Zavix Tower needs work but it is addictive and fun! Though it's a bit buggy and the interface/controls take a little bit to get used to, the game is really entertaining after that point. It feels like a true dungeon-crawler RPG, and I'd definitely recommend it, however only to those who are open minded to those who don't mind taking their time to understand undefined mechanics; this is not a finished game.

P.S. The guides section will help you find helpful information while you play. This guide by DEETS is a wonderful and in-depth guide that I'd highly recommend checking out while you play.

Pros:
+fun, addictive gameplay
+pretty good graphics
+skill tree
+upgradeable attributes
+hours of gameplay
+nostalgic RPG feeling
+customizable team/characters

Cons:
-confusing controls/mechanics
-occasional crashes
-sounds are basic and unappealing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, I love old school dungeon crawlers, starting from days of the Wizardry series and Proving Grounds of the Mad Overlord.  I've played every American Wizardry game and many of the Japanese ones.  I've played the old school Bard's Tales and Might & Magic games.  I say that so as to give you perspective on my review.

Visuals: These are always hit or miss for me.  I have a growing dislike of 'photo-realistic' graphics in games, so the slightly old-school/cartoony feel of the graphics is just about right for me in a 3D game.  Some of the animation is a little rough, but not in any way that detracts from the game for me. 4/5

Gameplay: For the most part this game is what I long for in a simple, old school dungeon crawler.  Explore the dungeon(Tower), kill bad guys, get loot.  There are, however, some downsides.  These, mostly, are centered around the free-to-play aspects.  For instance, inability to create a full party from the start, having to buy more bag space, etc.  These are not deal breakers, but they go to a trend in gaming that I don't like, false dificulty.  Challenge me with gameplay, not pay walls.  That said, those things haven't yet become game breaking or deal breaking, and can also be purchased with the in-game gold, which is a nice option for those of us that don't want to pay for micro transactions. Another thing I miss/haven't encountered are puzzles, secret doors, or some of the other standard Dungeon Crawl tropes.  If they are in the game, i just haven't found them yet, otherwise, i think the game misses out on something. I give it a tentative 3/5, 4/5 if the microtransactions remain unneeded to progress in the game.

Music/audio: I just stopped playing a few minutes ago, and I can't recall either the music or sound effects.  That could be because they aren't memorable or because the only thing I can hear is the sound of my sick elderly cat wheeze/snoring beside me.  ?/5 until I can play without the old windbag next to me.

Overall: The game is great fun, but definately has the Early Access feeling of an unpolished game.  That isn't bad, it means they're doing it the right way, still working, and constant updates are flowing.  As long as the devs keep doing what they're doing, i'm sure the game will keep getting better.  Keep up the good work, Devs, and i'll keep playing.

The only suggestion/request I can make would be to offer a version that we can pay for, that removes the microtransactions.  It is easier for me to justify a one time payment of 10, 20, 30, or 40 then an indefinate amount on a game currency.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of those addicting little gems. It fills a niche that hasn't been scratched since the 90's. A simple, fun, play at your pace, rpg-style, flash, dungeon crawler. Reminiscent of Bards Tale.

You will not need spreed sheets for economy, crafting recipes, or vast inventory spaces for hoarding every item you ever looted from a bandit. You ~will~ need to plan your stats, smacks, and strats!
-It matters where you allocate those attribute points per level.
-Also what enemy you target, and when.
-As well as how you budget mana and maintain health(especially on a boss level).

The devs & community are in that newlywed phase. So they are active with quick daily responses to work out kinks and explore it's direction.
It's a nice addition to anyones library fond of the genre. And if you like bieng envoled with and playing the early development release phase of games.

It's free with a cash shop. There are two currencies:
1) your standard Gold that's droped from mobs, selling loot & earned via daily quest
2) blue shard things bought with real money &/or earned via daily quest
They are both used to buy the same things, and you can earn both in game. So playing fully for free applies here.
No red flags or walls with the cash shop, it's just used to upgrade the town quicker/support the devs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, let me say that the Reviews" for all types of games here in Steam is just players opinions and thoughts and not ment to "hold your hands to walk you through" of what choice to make. Because the game is free you can give it a try and then decide yourself if you like it or not.

Now to the "main dish" (even though I am not good in writting reviews)Zavix Tower brings the "old school" board games into first prespective view of player by controlling your characters in this RPG game style
recommended:
characters stats and confronting bosses (as you walking towards higher tower floors) included.

there isn't anything there to make you OP as there isn't any PvP in the game.

There is also a "Starter Pack" that costs $1.99 (I think it was 1.78 Euro) which will give you a little help (if you want) to start your adventures but only is enabled for purchase for 24 hours and then it will go away or when your purchase it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the best game I ever played in 1996.  The only problem is it's not 1996, it's 2016.

Look, this game is actually pretty fun for what it is.  What it is; a procedural dungeon crawler with a fun late 90s vibe.  If you played and enjoyed those games, you'll like this.  It's done well and the cash shop doesn't feel like it's beaten over your head.  It's a free to play game, you could kill a little time with it, or not.  But honestly for free, it's really not too bad.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are looking for a fun dungeon delver that you can pass the time with from a few minutes to an hour or more, without the need to deal with any deep storyline or complex quests, then this game may be just what you are looking for.

It's basically a 1st person grid-based movement, turn-based combat, kill anything that moves and hope for cool equipment drops or chest loot kind of game....nothing really much deeper than that.

Explore floors and hit all the rooms before taking the stairs you should have found at some time then decide, go to the next level and fight even stronger monsters for (hopefully) better drops (and consequently, better chance of getting party members killed) or back to town to sort and sell loot, and hope for some nice epic piece to have found itself for sale on the blacksmith (and hope you can afford it if it does lol)

The game is constantly being updated with new features and bug fixes and is slowly evolving, between the Dev's vision for the game and input from the game's player-base, so I'm sure the game will get even better down the road.

Though the game DOES have a cash shop feature, so far I've yet to feel any need or great desire to even look at it, much less use it, as a free player, and have been enjoying the game as such. Mind you, personally I'm not a fan of cash shop games as a general rule, and feel the game would be much better served to just offer a paid full" version that simply includes the things I think are offered for sale such as more storage and revive ability or some such
date: but thats just my personal opinion
recommended: and doesn't effect the fact that played as a free game
voteText: March 29

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay, I revisited the game and this is what it felt like:

The gameplay is fluid enough now, its not too slow and not too fast, everyone can play it in their own pace.
The characters are okay, somewhat customizable, nothing too spectacular.

The combat is what you would expect from a game like this.
Everyone has their useful (and useless) abilities.

I have a hard time deciding if I actually like the game or not.

Pros:
-Runs on a potato
-It has the 'classic vibe'
-quite easy to pick up and play, but you can use advanced strategies too
-Somewhat nice loot
-Exelent difficuty curve, easy enough in the beginning, gets challenging later
-free

Cons:
-The graphics are meh. Not oldschool and a bit dissapointing, especcially the animations, but overall it does not matter too much.
-The 'dungeons' or floors are too similar, every rom looks almost exactly the same, a little variety would be absolutely cool.
-Everything is expensive as hell. Seriously. Gladly, its all IGC (In Game Currency)

Conclusion: After my revisit, I found the game actually quite pleasing and enjoyable, its not perfect, but the developers are working hard on it, so I can actually safely reccomend it to anyone, who like this genre!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a F2P Dungeon Crawler it is really well done.

There are only a few things what need to be improved:
1. The battlelog
Needs to be a tick smaller and if possible in a small black box so you can see the text better.

2. The loot system:
For RNG the loot is very well done, the only thing that bugs me is that nearly everything you collect has no real value.
You guys should increase the vcalues of items because once I equiped my guys with good loot I just discarded my old stuff instead of selling it.

3. Locked doors:
Having a small window pop up to decide if you want to open it or not makes it a bit more comfortable instead of going into the inventory and drag and drop the key onto the door.

4. Free camera:
I've played Star Crawlers in the past and I loved the free looking feature in it. Holding the middle button of your mouse to look around you in 360° would be cool (not a must have just... a feature ;D)

That is all for now. I know this game is early access and I love that you guys update this game frequently. If, by any chance, you read my review of this game you could consider my improvement suggestions if you want.

So the final question is: Do I recommend the game?
I say yes. Sure it got some flaws but heck it's free to play. It is a simple game made by only 2 people and tested by another. Give the game some time and you gonna love it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Classic-style, loot-based dungeon crawler that feels more like a phone game, complete with microtransactions for gems. The game itself, in spite of its simplicity, scratches the right itch for quick-access RPG elements when you don't have time to navigate a 3D worldspace to get to your objective. When my rogue got one-shotted on the first floor, stuff got real. The turn-based combat is challenging, and makes you appreciate every single hp. This game certainly deserves a place in its niche.

Upon perusing the in-game cash shop, you'll find the standard slate of $1.99 to $59.99 gem packages that we've all come to loathe. Nothing kills an RPG chubby faster than an in-game cash shop. It breaks immersion every time I have to employ my self-discipline to deny myself the luxuries of bag space, rezzing my heroes, hiring new ones, etc. However, if you can shrug off the temptation, you'll probably love this game.

https://imgur.com/a/XHTId

For PC, there are quite a few titles out there that can deliver a similar experience, minus the cash-grab. If you need a good game for a low-end PC, Forgotten Realms' Baldur's Gate comes to mind, which has even been improved upon as the genre has matured.

To the devs: You're on to something potentially amazing. A clean RPG experience will always have an eager market. FTL and Terraria (BtP) are amazing, timeless games because every player stands on equal ground. Please drop the microtransactions, put a price on your hard work, and rebalance the cash shop rewards into the game as part of its progression. With your current monetization strategy, I can't recommend this title to anyone I know.


************************************************************
************************************************************
Edit:

I've been informed that the cash shop will be shut down, and the game will be released as a paid title. This is a terrific decision - the traditional monetization model is one that we can all get behind without feeling guilty about impulsive purchasing. Game was free the first time, and I will gladly buy again upon release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have only played a little under a half hour of this game so far. The Concept is the tried and true formula of dungeon crawling but the execution leaves a bit to be desired.

My main issue is the loot mechanic, if you get a reward after a battle or after a floor clear, you have to make sure you drag each individual item into your backpack one by one to collect the reward. For the first few battles,and even on the floor clear loot, I was clicking the 'ok' button thinking it was putting the loot in my pack, after I cleared the first floor I went back to town to check my spoils. Apparently clicking OK, without dragging each individual item over, makes the loot vanish into thin air, you cannot recover any loot lost this way, it doesn't fall into a pile to pick up later it just goes away.

The lighting on the models is very simple, it would be decent quality as a mobile game but on PC I would expect a little more polish and care put into the models so the light looked good on them rather than blocky or dark.

Sound is simple enough, basic slashing sounds and such.

Overall this game may shape up to be a good time waster in the future, but with some mechanics that are fiddly at best and not non-gamer friendly at worst, you may want to let this wait in the oven for a bit longer while they work on polish.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tried it because it is free. Simplistic dungeon crawler with ugly art, lackluster music, and some uninteresting sound effects. No charm, no wonder, the structure is very rigid and predictable, if there are any puzzles in it, I pray they are more interesting than the combat and exploration. There was hardly any discovery to be had, and combat was in almost every room. Misses the point of being a dungeon crawler

Game encourages microtransactions, not mandatory, but not a good sign for a free game of this caliber either. Not going to pay in microtransactions for a game that doesn't grab me, to hope that this money will make the game better in the future is foolishness.

There are many dungeon crawlers out there that are better than this one, most if not all much older too. Play those instead.
voteText: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I dont usually write reviews. So here it goes.
Tried it, and become attached easily. Thats because im a maniac in RPG games in general.
But I dont think I can recommend this game for now. Why? The punishment is so severe when your party is annihilated. after all party member is killed, returning to town found out all gears in the inventory AND equipped to my active party members that i obtained is gone. Furthermore I have to spend in-game gold to revive the main character. I personally dont like that kind of punishment. I know its F2P, but, really? Thats how you treat your clients?

There's a possible workaround for the penalty. My suggestions :
+ Experience penalty.
+ in-game gold deduction according to deaths at certain floor.
+ dailies deduction.

but please, not deleting the whole gears in the inventory. For now im giving it a forced thumbs down. Ill probably return to this game, if the penalty is being lifted.


(Edit)
1 bug detected while playing.
while i was changing of a greater gear of the main character (dont remember what it is, chest or belt maybe) the health was deducted by one. I thought it was because of the low stat, but when i re-equipped the old one, still deducted by one. when i repeatedly changing of the 2 gear, the health is deducted until 0 but the char is still alive (happened in the dungeon)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFaily poorly executed game in my opinion. I was able to completely crash and bug the game which, for some wierd reason duplicated my entire party in the tavern in the first 30 minutes of play. Forcing me to delete and restart. Maybe this is an old school love thing, but for me, not worth my time on this freebie.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOldschool style dungeon crawler.....with microtransactions? True you can technically play it without spending anything, but it's not really worth it when you consider how limited you are upon starting a new game and the fact that each upgrade" to the town or your inventory space increases in cost
date: starting at 25 shards for the first one and 50 shards for the second in each category. I've not bought any upgrades so I'm not sure if it increases by 25 each time or increases by an order of magnitude.\n\n16 inventory slots to start with
recommended: which you will most likely fill up in the first floor of the dungeon
hoursPlayed: since you start at floor one on entering it means you'll have to skip a lot of loot. Not TOO terrible when most of the loot on the first few floors sells for less than 10 gp each unless it's a magical item and it's best to just skip even picking it up if you're planning on moving to other floors
voteText: but you'll soon find yourself having to stop after each fight to pick and choose what to discard and to pick up. Sure
helpfulPercent: you could spend shards to upgrade your inventory by 4 slots per upgrade but why is it such a piddly amount of spaces to begin with?\n\nOne of the selling points of the game is a "persistant upgradeable town"
votesHelpful: but the "upgrades" only address the sad state of each building instead of adding something meaningful to them. Starting off the Blacksmith restocks 4 items each time you finish a romp in the tower and the Tavern has one recruit available each refresh. But
votesTotal: hey! You can spend shards to upgrade them! Awesome. It also costs gold or shards to recruit more characters beyond the initial 4. I can't recall ever having to pay to recruit other adventurers in any other dungeon crawler that I've played.\n\nThe true oldschool dungeon crawlers like Bard's Tale and the Wizardry games have fully functional towns
votesFunny: so why doesn't this one? Because it's "free"? Is it really "free" if you have to shell out cash to "build" the town from what is apparently a backwater hovel?\n\nAvoid
commentsCount: there are much better dungeon crawlers out there that don't try to milk you for money."
